newsitem.title: LITHUANIA: C.BANK SAYS NO IMF LOANS AFTER SEPT - REPORT.
newsitem.headline: C.BANK SAYS NO IMF LOANS AFTER SEPT - REPORT.

text.p: Bank of Lithuania governor Reinoldijus Sharkinas said that the country no longer required IMF credits after its memorandum with the fund expires in September, daily Lietuvos rytas reported on Thursday.
"Unless unpredictable circumstances arise," there will be no need to borrow further funds from the IMF, the paper quoted Sharkinas as saying.
The paper reported Sharkinas as saying that the central bank was carrying out all of its obligations under the current memorandum and that it had sufficient foreign currency reserves.
The bank's offcial reserves at the end of March were $813.9 million, up from $795 million at the end of February.

Sharkinas' comments echoed earlier statements made by Prime Minister Gediminas Vagnorius, who said in March that the country had reached a stage in its transition to capitalism where it no longer needed to borrow from the fund.
Lithuania has borrowed a total of around 200 million SDRs from the IMF, the fund's office in Lithuania said.
